And once more we said the currencies disturbed the picture.
Yeah. Well then coming back into the U.K. question. Do you have there anything to share with us, when you're going to be back in profitable – a lot of profitability on your U.K. business?
Well, the U.K. business is profitable but not enough.
Yeah, yeah.
Its value destructive for the moment.

No, correct. Yes, and so when you look at the operational performance of the U.K., the operating margin of the U.K. that is clearly too low, that's below all the benchmarks we have in the company. So we will work hard to bring it up to the company levels, but that is not something of short-term.
So you can take longer than three years that's...
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Yeah?
Sure.
Thank you. And on the asset sales?

On the asset sales, we operate only core assets. Let me put that upfront and the asset sales are more in the light of – in all operations you have kind of assets like real estate pieces of, pieces of land which you have around and which might not be of necessary use. So, all these operations are in the hand for cash program like we did three, four, five years ago. We redo it again. And all these assets are screened and the assets which are not necessary for the proper business that they've been disposed. That's the .
Are you looking at a couple of million, or a couple of dozens of millions, or hundreds of millions?

The timing is difficult. If you look at the big ones then it's, for instance, when we close Berkshire Brewery, you have the big piece of land and the arriving, the closure of the Beamish & Crawford brewery, you have a site in Cork, a prime site, and the thing we will have to balance is, do you go for a quick sale at probably completely the wrong time or do you – do that slightly later and project-by-project we will look – look at that.
All right. Thank you.
We have a question from the line now.
The next question comes from Karel Zoete from Rabo Securities. Please go ahead.

Yes, good afternoon. Two questions if I may. First one on your wholesale operations in Europe which is a sizeable for you, how is this business coping with say, lower volumes from already rough – well rather thin margins as well as that many bar owners are having a tough time by providing them credits? Second question with regard to media range, because media has a big customer for you ... what are you seeing with the rates, are they down to 10%, 20%, little bit more color on that please? Thank you.

I'll take the wholesale, you take the media. The wholesale business is – is definitely in Europe, under pressure, because the on trade business is clearly the one which is the most under pressure at this time, so the name of the game is to restructure. We do that constantly. We were doing that already before the recession, the trend of a negative – negative trend in the on trade is already busy for quite a number of years. So it is a game of resizing your infrastructure.

Wholesale is a regional business, so you have to resize your infrastructure, resize your offering; examples as we are offering a coffee line in the Netherlands as an additional business because there is business there, so to improve your top line on the cost size, we resize the business in order to restore as quickly as we can the kind of operating margins we work with – with net, net are indeed very thin. But these wholesale businesses are instrumental to give us the market shares in the on trade business in the major countries where we operate in Europe that is why we keep them. But they are of course more sensible to fluctuation and they call for always for the most urgent action not to let them down. And if I look back, you've seen in the result of the Fit 2 Fight, 22% of the 468 million savings realized over the last two years have been wholesaling and that is of course mainly in our wholesaling Western Europe. So, going forward, we'll continue to focus on that one.
And with regard to credits – in the businesses there?
Sorry.
With regard to credits, – plus you – well the wholesale business obviously had quite some credits to buyers which are having a tough time.

It's hard time and I think everybody does the same, right? So, we look at our creditors in some countries. We might accept slightly increasing bad debt coming out of that business. But not to a tune which would endanger the business of course, but that is absolute the priority of the Managers out there is to manage that very, very tightly indeed. And then on the media cost, yes you see in certain countries price is going down by real substantial amounts, up to 30-40%, but don't apply that to our total sales and marketing cost because there is much more in that than just media. And on the other hand, you see sponsorships, for instance our long-term views as – so there you don't have that effect, so it is a mixed bag but television, printed media is it going down rapidly.
Thank you.
The next question comes from Robert Jan Vos from Fortis. Please go ahead.

Sorry, good afternoon. I have two questions. I would like to get back on CapEx briefly. You said that the 700 million guided for '09 includes this overflow from expansion plans that were started in '07, '08. Does this mean that in '010 and '011 your CapEx could go materially lower than the 700 million guided for '09? That's my first question. My second question is on dividend. You could have kept your dividends stable and still be within a payout of 32 to 35% or be at more towards the high end of that range. Can you explain why you decided to cut your dividends? Thank you.

For the CapEx, yes, it's – that leads to the question. If you deduct the overflow from, you can say well that's the new level of investment. And whilst you could think that, we would not pin ourselves to that because once more might drives opportunities or we would have to face replacement investments, which are absolutely necessary. But sure, the overflow of the year '08 indicates that there is room to maneuver going forward without giving a particular number in the next two years going forward.

And then secondly on the dividends, yes factually you're right. We could have maintained the $0.70 and stayed in the – within the policy and what we propose now is within the policy as well. The reason why we have taken the point as low as possible in the policy is from a conservative point of view. When you look at balance sheet, you see that we have 8.9 billion in debt which we want to bring down, so we have more stakeholders than only shareholders and we share the burden bit equally.
Okay. Thank you.
Okay. Questions from the room. Who was not...
Ian has already...
Ian has not – here, third one from the ...his first time with us.

Ian Shackleton from Nomura. Just going back to the input cost comment that you made earlier on about it being flattish this year. Two questions around that. As we go through the year, presuming things get easier, you still have some hedging in place after the first half, so should we expect, sort of, much better situation in the second half? And how does it work across the regions? I mean, we know a number of your competitors are probably more hedged in Western Europe, unless it's in emerging markets. Does it work like that for you as well?
Can you comment on them at all?

Yes, these are very differentiated and complicated picture because ultimately it's an add-on of different contractors, different durations and different geographies. So it is not something which you will see equally across the company. That's right. But I find it difficult and I am not able to specify and we don't want to specify that region-by-region or country-by-country.
But just to clarify, when you do say flattish, that is taking account of any currency inflation in emerging markets where commodities are linked to euro, dollar as well.

No, so what we say is that in euro terms, we go to an flattish situation that will mean for companies and that is the discussion we had with over the question of Nico, that obviously in Central and Eastern Europe for instance, you will see an important input cost inflation, because the devaluation of the local currencies.
And are any of those questions that about the sort of hard currency percentage of COGS. Say, I mean, if we were to work in sort of 25, 30% type level of total COGS is that totally out of line?
Yeah, we report differently, but only our raw and packaging, including transport cost is 4 billion in the company and that is to a great extent our ad currency linked.

It's that the mitigation is in Central and Eastern Europe. There is where you have the most for Africa, you have much less. But it depends. Countries like Nigeria can decide to lower the malt intake. We have been able to deliver even a 100% malt there which is of a perfect quality. I am not saying we are going to do that, but we have that kind of mitigations in countries like Africa to go more for local sourcing. Central Europe, I have been pointing out already, we have our own malting operation in Slovakia. We can also, you know, if we sell in euros, amongst ourselves, it is finally coming into the – our own operation. So you have a number of mitigation factors there. To give you a precise proportion is difficult at this moment in time.
Nico, you have the microphone.

Hi, Edward Santos from Dynamo Capital. Just two quick questions. First of them is 2.5 times of debt to EBITDA is a target for 2009 or 2009 and beyond? And the other one just a follow-on on commodity cost, are you still 50% hedged for 2009 and if you could give us an idea of coverage for 2010? And the third and last one, in the non-core assets, which you list for an eventual sale, do you include the U.K. pubs as a non-core asset?

To start with last thing no, we see the pubs as absolutely core and SNP as core of our business. The net debt EBITDA is a level which we aim for as a company, but that is not something we will reach in 2009, but we have said we will focus on cash generation. We will pay down debt and the 2.5 times is a level we feel that that should be the level the company is at. And for the hedges, the 50% coverage was when we communicated around August. This level is now substantially higher in input cost are contracted.
For '010 any?

And for '010 I don't, well malt is a thing you do year-by-year and are some contracts, which are longer term contracts, but that is not a big part of the input cost. Our hopes are normally longer term contracts -

Long term – Yeah, hopes are contracts from three to five years. And molt is yearly, and that depends on the crop essentially, on the supply and the quality of the crop. So that's – that might be very volatile and that's for sure. Aluminum, we – in today's we have to buy the aluminum for the producers. In the old days the producers was doing it himself. We kind of take positions on the aluminum market, so that is also depending of what the aluminum market will going forward. Though it is not as important than in Coca-Cola; Coca-Cola as a real big business in to canning, for us it's much lower.

And glass, you have to reckon it's very much linked to the price of the energy, 22 to 25% of the price of the glass bottle is derived from the energy prices, and so most of the contracts even if we make them long-term, we have – we variabilize the energy component in it as not to have too many occasions lost, I can say that. That's how it works, grossly, what I can say.
Thank you.

JPMorgan Asset Management. Just going back to the S & N acquisition model, can you remind us how many years it was going to take for you originally to reach your weighted average cost of capital? And it sounds like, you know, it could be another three years additionally to that to reach that target, particularly if you add in the extra restructuring costs. You know, the full in cost of the S & N acquisition, I mean are we looking at 8 years before we actually reach the white?
We have as you have read in the release, we have withdrawn the four years and we have not given another timeframe. So that will be longer.
So we – but are we talking – double that level now, I mean eight years is, you know, a realistic timeframe?
As we don't have given an outlook for this year, we don't know where the economy is going to; we are not going to give you any indication of that.

Thank you. It's Nico Lambrechts, again. Just a question on Russia, I see you – and you get that – you put price increases of 4.5% percent through in the first quarter, was that the market leader that put them through and you followed?

Follow-on question, when you did your impairment exercise you obviously had to make volume assumptions et cetera to get your MPV. Could you indicate what your volume assumptions were in the short-term and longer term for Russian market? And then there are shifts around the excise between spirits and beer in the Russian market, if you update us on that and how a move towards cheaper vodka et cetera could be impacted by excise changes?
The 4.5%, which we applied, I'm not sure, if we were first or the others first, were you awake at 7 o'clock? I don't what they have said this morning. Honestly, I don't know.

Okay. Autonomously it was not kind of an immediate follow-up, but it's obvious that we have – we need to have the room in the market. We are a number three player. Our aim, of course, we have always said it is to increase our share. We have increased our share of market this year by a full percentage point. That's good news. But of course, in terms of pricing power in Russia, we are not as strong as if we would be in the leader position. We are not so strong as we would be in Poland or Slovakia or... So that plays a role of course. But I think this time took it on an autonomous movement of ourselves, yeah.
This price increase was actually put through by Heineken, because the market leader didn't talk about price increases this morning.
No. It might be well, so I'm not 100% sure, but...
Okay. Do you want it?

No. The only think what I can say, last year we priced about 2% higher than – and this year we haven't seen all the gap because of prices. We did it in February, and I haven't seen anything about that.

But you also have, because we always talk pricing as a result and done our full portfolio brands. You don't do pricing as I put, it's on certain brands that you take, and that gives you a kind of an average pricing advantage you move. And so the decision is very much taken in our portfolio where other brands can support some price increases because the equity is improving, the demand is there, they're growing, and we feel you know, you can get a little bit more out of it. That's how we go about it.
And volume outlook and potential excise shifts?
I wouldn't go to outlook in Russia. Nor outlook on the markets, nor on the volume shifts. No, I leave that to our friends in Denmark.

Hello. Two questions. Kris Kippers from Petercam in Brussels. Firstly, on the U.S. market, we've seen Heineken volumes going down significantly, whereas FEMSA is keeping up relatively well. How afraid are you of the situation between your big Belgium competitor and its negotiations with Modelo, concerning for example, cross selling possibilities in the U.S.? And secondly, could you confirm or not confirm officially whether Heineken is really looking at certain assets of this indebted competitor? Thank you.

First of all, the growth rates between Heineken and FEMSA. Look, the price point of the FEMSA portfolio is absolutely not the same that from Heineken. Heineken has the price point of 50 above those activities which is – it's much, much smaller than Heineken is growing from a lower base. So it has the excitement of the novelty but it prices at 30%. So and the last and the other brand the Kulta is pricing at difference of 10% above domestic max. So that is more of a mainstream brand if you will and a mainstream plus brand than really being a premium brand. That explains why, combined with very good marketing, these brands are growing at a rapid pace. And I think I explained already the two reasons why Heineken is under pressure, but that just to understand the mechanics and put them in their context.

Now, the second part of your question relates to of course, speculations. And absolutely not up for me to comment. One has to say about the distribution system. Look, 65% of our volumes transit through mailer chorus – now more and more mailer chorus distributors that is secret to nobody. And so this is traditionally how we have been distributing the beer in the United States. It is not in the interest of the distributors to be totally dependent on one sole supplier. We offered them a brand with anti margin and velocity. So we are very strong with our distributors. We have built relations over – also decades they're all family businesses as you know the distributorship is protected by the U.S. system in most of the states, so going forward any combinations of competitors, yes they put more pressure in the market, but do not forget the independence of distributors and the power of the brands and the people behind that who build them.
Your second question was about assets of ABNF?
Yes.

Well as a general comment, we never comment on anything like business development or acquisitions, but let me make a general comment, as you have seen in the presentation, first priority in the company is cash generation, paying down debt that is from an financial point of view. But also managerially, we have a lot on our plate, we have 11 new markets, which we have to bring up to speed and increase the profitability and so that is where we will focus.
Without any doubt.
Okay. No questions any more? Thank you very much. I think that's our hour, time for a beer.
